instruction: How were the machine learning models used in the investigation of the handheld near-infrared spectrometer for the identification of deposited bloodstains?
Output:
The machine learning models were used in the investigation of the handheld near-infrared spectrometer for the identification of deposited bloodstains by conducting a calibration process. Over 500 positive (blood present) and negative (blood absent) samples were scanned using the spectrometer to create a dataset for training the predictive models. These models were developed based on machine learning principles using the collected data.

After the calibration, the models were tested on over 100 new positive and negative samples to evaluate their performance. The purpose of this testing was to assess the accuracy and effectiveness of the models in correctly classifying deposited stains as blood. The results showed that all tested models were able to classify the stains as blood with at least 81% accuracy, and some models achieved even higher classification accuracy of over 94%.

This investigation demonstrated that the handheld near-infrared spectrometer, combined with machine learning models, has the potential to be a rapid, low-cost, and non-destructive method for screening body fluids at crime scenes, specifically for the identification of bloodstains.
